A new undergraduate natural
science degree program leading to
advanced degrees in Public
Health was unanimously
approved by the Academic
Council at its Wednesday
meeting.
The Council also voted to
retain both the first semester
freshman grading system and the

forms.

its approval by the Academic
Council of Hopkins' School of
Public Health and Hygiene,
which will provide funding for
the program.

SAC ratifies new set of by-laws
By JOE BUSCEMA
The Student Activiites
Commission (SAC) succeeded in
approving a set of guidelines and
by-laws for the reorganization of
the Commission, yesterday, in its
fifth meeting of the year.
The by-laws and guidelines
were ratified by a vote 25-3, with
3 abstentions. The acceptance of
this pact represented the
culmination of weeks of debate
and argument, in which
numerous proposals were put
forth by SAC members
modifying the original document
drafted by SAC Executive
Committee members Alan Fink,
Andrew Savitz, and Alan
Sapakie, and submitted October
3.
Despite the overwhelming vote
for ratification of the by-laws
and guidelines, dissent was heard
from certain SAC members,
including Sue Fino, who
summarized her feelings by
commenting,"This document is a
mess."
Fino alleged the by-laws and
guidelines were filled with
contradictions and advised the
rewriting of the document with
resubmission to the SAC after
intersession:
Andrew Savitz, Student
Council President, expressed his
belief that the by-laws and
guidelines contained problems,
blit these would be worked out
in time with their application.
Much of the discussion at the
meeting centered around the
institution of these by-laws and
guidelines as policy for the SAC.
The pact must be submitted now
to theStudent Council for its
approval. Assuming they are
accepted by the Council, the
by-laws and guidelines would
then be voted upon by students
in the form of a referendum.
Certain SAC members stressed
the need for rapid action and
implementation of the approved
rules and expressed
disappointment when Savitz

announced that a referendum
would not be held before the SC
general elections, the first week
of March.
Savitz pointed out that the SC
would not be able to come to a
decision on these SAC by-laws
until the end of this semester. In
response to a proposal for staging
a referendum coincident with
registration at the beginning of
the second semester, Savitz
contended that this would
deprive students of the
opportunity to evaluate the
document carefully. He
expressed his belief that waiting a
number of weeks would obviate
the difficulty associated with
staging an additional referendum.
Nevertheless, certain
resolutions were adopted by the
SAC concerning the
implementation of the by-laws.
One of these included a motion
to immediately institute the
provisions of the document
should it receive student approval
through the referendum.
Another motion, put forth by
Edward Brokans, called upon the
SC to ts_mporarily' institute the

by-laws effective between the
time the SC adopts them and the
student referendum. Both
resolutions were approved
overwhelmingly.
Following the various votes, as
Chairman Fink was ready to
embark upon what he called "the
real purpose of the SAC," the
meeting degenerated into a
discussion of Fink's "disparaging
remarks" concerning SAC
members whom he dubbed as
"groping for power."
Edward Brokans expressed his
personal dissatisfaction, calling
upon Fink to apologize for his
statements. Fink refused to
comment on this issue.

Library to use computer system
The MSE Library is in the
process of purchasing a $136,000
computer system to replace its
present mechanism for the
circulation of its holdings,
revealed Head Librarian• David
Stam.
Including implementation
expenditures, the cost of the
installation of the new system
could run as high as $200,000. If
the purchase is finalized this
Bionth as anticipated, the system
will be in partial use by March
and in full use by this summer,
Stam indicated.
Stam said that he expects that
the system, once it is completely
installed, will save the library
from $35,000 to $50,000 a year.
He also said that the system
will provide far better service for
the readers since it is in an "on
line" system that has information
stored and ready for recall as
soon as it is entered, as opposed
to the present "batch processing"
system where information
recorded by the system is often
"locked" in the system for as
many as four days.
"We'll have a better system
that will save money," Stam

commented. "The point of this
change is econorny and 1)etter
service."
The Library plans to purohase
the system from Computer
Library Services, Inc. The Ci_SI
has also sold a system to Harvard
University f& its library of eight
million volumes.
"We're just as confident as can
be that this is the fastest, most
efficient circulation system that
we can get into," asserted Stam.
Though the library is currently
beseiged by several pressing
problems other than the
"obsolete circulation system,"
including the renovation of the
Gilman Library Stacks, Stam
maintained that "after talking
over the library's priorities at
length...we decided that this is
very high priority."
Under the proposed
circulation systea all books will
be encoded and identified with a
pattern of lines similar to those
on milk cartons for spoilage
dates—and would be charged out
at the circulation desk by passing
them through an optical scanner.
As soon as the book has been
passed through the optical scan,

the transaction will be recorded
on the computer and can be
called up at any time by the
library to determine the
whereabouts of the book.
Batch-Processing
With the batch-processing
system at the MSE now, the call
numbers of books are
photographed, punched on to
computer cards, and then fed
through the
University's
computer system to yield a
print-out of all library
transactions.
The Library spends roughly
$40,000 alone each year on
computer processing costs, Stam
disclosed.

Under the proposed system,
students who could not find a
book on one of the levels of the
library will be able to call the
circulation desk of the library
and ascertain the status of the
book immediately.
Efficiency
Stam inaicated that all savings
in the system will come from the
efficiencies of the system. The
system will not cause a reduction
in library personnel.

Attorneys John Wheeler Glenn
and John F. King presented the
plaintiff's and defendant's

be overcome by the jury.

negligence by a professional, in

"Don't go into practice
without ample insurance
coverage—there's no telling when
it will occur, not only from acts

patient's left arm instead of his
right leg) or commission."

By CLAYTON BLICK
A few weeks ago I penned an epic
dissertation on the relative merits of AM
radio in general and five local stations.
The AM situation was found to be lacking
in quality, but not •misrepresentative 9f
the situation nationwide.
Well, Baltimore has found itself even
more lacking on the FM side, where the
quality should be of a higher level.
Originally, the idea of FM was to expand
the available air space but without the
problems of AM, primarily static
overcrowding, and late night drift and
other atmospherics. The 88-108
megacycle band (between channels 6 and
7 on the TV) is well suited for this
purpose, sacrificing only range to line of
sight transmissions. This drawback has
made FM's acceptance to the car radio
format unpredictable and worth the cost
of FM-installation in a car only in a city
of major size and quality programming.
FM radio has therefore become a
format restricted to the quality home
system or at least the second band of the
portable radio. Also the possibility of
stereo and even quadraphonic sound adds
to the possibilities of the "elitists" radio.
Quality stereo reception is dependent on
the use of an antenna of sufficient merit
to provide signal separation, just as color
TV needs a better antenna. If you obtain
a good antenna your troubles are still not
over as station quality is lacking to a
degree not realized by most. True stereo
and quad are effective but lacking the
sophistication that is possible.

FM radio was originally conceived as
primarily a classical music venture that
would provide the technical quality to
those who so desired. Of course, classical
music could never fill the financial
requirements of the commercial radio
station, and the medium became quickly
"tainted" with"inferior" music. The
group of uncouth Bohemians who
listened to this drivel soon filled these
sacred airwaves with more AM type
music, but until recently this shocking
cacophony was kept to as tasteful a level
as possible.
Of course this cacophony is simply the
music that most people listen to
everyday. For most of us Beethoven is
just too demanding to our attention. So
FM now offers progressive rock, easy
listening, "progressive" country music,
and jazz, in addition to classical. The
word progressive itself was spawned
specifically for FM in an attempt to gain
an elitist aura and remains to promote
some semblance of quality programming.
Searching for decent FM stations is not
an easy task. Right away we can eliminate
the easy-listening format. More than any
other type of programming this not-only
grates on my ear, but insults my
intelligence as well. Dinner _nusic, or
better termed, elevator music, brings to
mind 1) eating in the Homewood Deli, 2)
riding in the elevator of a suburban
department store, or 3) waiting for my
teeth to be pulled as the drill digs deep
into the bicuspids of my dentist's current
patient. This music is so predictable with

its Ray Coniff Choruses, Walter Wonderly
organs, and the 1001 strings, that it
gushes with more butter than is on that
potato, stuck in your throat at dinner. I
find that most people who enjoy listening
to this music are either deaf, cardiac
patients, or more probably people who
do not like to listen to music. This logic
of "I put that music on so we could
talk," or "I don't listen to the radio, I
just keep it on for mood in the
background," escapes me as
mood-creating music must be heard and
to be properly heard must be listened to.
Country music on FM seems out of
place, as I feel that it is best suited to the
AM band. But my preferences have , led
me away from this probably acceptable
format which strikes a bit too lush and
twangy. Pleading ignorance I can
therefore offer no suggestions on this, the
funkiest of all musical forms.
Classical music is handled by WCAO,

By LESLIE BOWMAN
The long planned, long awaited, and
greatly needed new wing of the Walters
Art Gallery has finally opened. The
opening took place two years later than
had originally been planned, due to
construction problems and numerous
other difficulties, but, the impressive
fanfare and celebration of the opening
ceremonies provided more than adequate
compensation for the long wait. There
were two galas, one on Thursday evening,
the fourteenth of November, for
members of the Gallery and local guests,
and another on Friday the fifteenth, for
the out-of-town guests and lenders to the
exhibits. Saturday marked the official
opening for the public. A ribbon cutting
cermony with Mayor Schaeffer officiating
was followed by tours of the new gallery
space, given by highly qualified and
well-trained docents.
I had the good fortune to attend the
Thursday evening ceremonies. Guests
arrived in heavy coats and huddled under
umbrellas, and fashionable ladies hopped
about trying to avoid soaking the hems of
long dresses in the massive puddles on
streets and sidewalks outside the gallery.
It appeared initially that fickle Nature
would dampen the festival spirit. But.
once one reached the Mount Vernor
Place entrance, where great peals ot
medieval trumpets sounded their
greetings, one quickly forgot the rain and
gloom what with the warm and exciting
atmosphere inside.
After a two year wait for the new wing
to open, a twenty minute wait in the
reception line seemed tolerable. Then, the

were not disappointed. The new wing is,
in a word, fantastic. It represents a radical
departure from the conventional design
of. interior space in most museums.
Traditionally, museums have consisted of
a series of rectangular galleries stemming
from an interior courtyard. The
Baltimore Museum of Art and the
Metropolitan Museum of New York are
both designed this way. as are countless
other major museum's. In this sort of
traditional building, the visitor is
continually forced back inward. Not so in
the new wing at the Walters. Although
technically there is a central core, one
doesn't get the feeling of walking in the
usual circular path. There is great variety
in the structural design of each individual
gallery. Dropped floors and cul-de-sacs
which suddenly appear before the visitor,
ramps and unusual lighting techniques, all
use the architectural elements of the
building to enhance the exhibits in a
delightful and inspiring way. I especially
enjoyed the impressive exhibit of
medieval tapestries, and the collection of
ancient sarcophagi.
The new wing has added 100,000
square feet of space to the Gallery, of
which about half will be for permanent
exhibitions. With this additional space, up
to eighty percent of the Walters
collection will be on permanent display.

By CLAYTON BLICK
A few weeks ago I penned an epic
dissertation on the relative merits of AM
radio in general and five local stations.
The AM situation was found to be lacking
in quality, but not •misrepresentative 9f
the situation nationwide.
Well, Baltimore has found itself even
more lacking on the FM side, where the
quality should be of a higher level.
Originally, the idea of FM was to expand
the available air space but without the
problems of AM, primarily static
overcrowding, and late night drift and
other atmospherics. The 88-108
megacycle band (between channels 6 and
7 on the TV) is well suited for this
purpose, sacrificing only range to line of
sight transmissions. This drawback has
made FM's acceptance to the car radio
format unpredictable and worth the cost
of FM-installation in a car only in a city
of major size and quality programming.
FM radio has therefore become a
format restricted to the quality home
system or at least the second band of the
portable radio. Also the possibility of
stereo and even quadraphonic sound adds
to the possibilities of the "elitists" radio.
Quality stereo reception is dependent on
the use of an antenna of sufficient merit
to provide signal separation, just as color
TV needs a better antenna. If you obtain
a good antenna your troubles are still not
over as station quality is lacking to a
degree not realized by most. True stereo
and quad are effective but lacking the
sophistication that is possible.

FM radio was originally conceived as
primarily a classical music venture that
would provide the technical quality to
those who so desired. Of course, classical
music could never fill the financial
requirements of the commercial radio
station, and the medium became quickly
"tainted" with"inferior" music. The
group of uncouth Bohemians who
listened to this drivel soon filled these
sacred airwaves with more AM type
music, but until recently this shocking
cacophony was kept to as tasteful a level
as possible.
Of course this cacophony is simply the
music that most people listen to
everyday. For most of us Beethoven is
just too demanding to our attention. So
FM now offers progressive rock, easy
listening, "progressive" country music,
and jazz, in addition to classical. The
word progressive itself was spawned
specifically for FM in an attempt to gain
an elitist aura and remains to promote
some semblance of quality programming.
Searching for decent FM stations is not
an easy task. Right away we can eliminate
the easy-listening format. More than any
other type of programming this not-only
grates on my ear, but insults my
intelligence as well. Dinner _nusic, or
better termed, elevator music, brings to
mind 1) eating in the Homewood Deli, 2)
riding in the elevator of a suburban
department store, or 3) waiting for my
teeth to be pulled as the drill digs deep
into the bicuspids of my dentist's current
patient. This music is so predictable with

its Ray Coniff Choruses, Walter Wonderly
organs, and the 1001 strings, that it
gushes with more butter than is on that
potato, stuck in your throat at dinner. I
find that most people who enjoy listening
to this music are either deaf, cardiac
patients, or more probably people who
do not like to listen to music. This logic
of "I put that music on so we could
talk," or "I don't listen to the radio, I
just keep it on for mood in the
background," escapes me as
mood-creating music must be heard and
to be properly heard must be listened to.
Country music on FM seems out of

Classical music is handled by WCAO,

The long planned, long awaited, and
greatly needed new wing of the Walters

construction problems and numerous
other difficulties, but, the impressive
fanfare and celebration of the opening
ceremonies provided more than adequate
compensation for the long wait. There
were two galas, one on Thursday evening,

the out-of-town guests and lenders to the
exhibits. Saturday marked the official

space, given by highly qualified and
well-trained docents.
I had the good fortune to attend the
Thursday evening ceremonies. Guests
arrived in heavy coats and huddled under
umbrellas, and fashionable ladies hopped
about trying to avoid soaking the hems of
long dresses in the massive puddles on
streets and sidewalks outside the gallery.
It appeared initially that fickle Nature
would dampen the festival spirit. But.
once one reached the Mount Vernor
Place entrance, where great peals ot
medieval trumpets sounded their

a series of rectangular galleries stemming
from an interior courtyard. The
Baltimore Museum of Art and the
Metropolitan Museum of New York are
both designed this way. as are countless
other major museum's. In this sort of

delightful and inspiring way. I especially
enjoyed the impressive exhibit of
medieval tapestries, and the collection of
ancient sarcophagi.

square feet of space to the Gallery, of
